service.name: Amazon OpsWorks
service.documentation: AWS OpsWorks provides a simple and flexible way to create and manage stacks and applications. With AWS OpsWorks, you can provision AWS resources, manage their configuration, deploy applications to those resources, and monitor their health.

cabal.name: Amazon OpsWorks
cabal.description: AWS OpsWorks provides a simple and flexible way to create and manage stacks and applications. With AWS OpsWorks, you can provision AWS resources, manage their configuration, deploy applications to those resources, and monitor their health.

contents.name: _astInstanceCount
contents.documentation: The number of instances to add or remove when the load exceeds a threshold.

contents.name: _astThresholdsWaitTime
contents.documentation: The amount of time, in minutes, that the load must exceed a threshold before more instances are added or removed.

contents.name: _astIgnoreMetricsTime
contents.documentation: The amount of time (in minutes) after a scaling event occurs that AWS OpsWorks should ignore metrics and not raise any additional scaling events. For example, AWS OpsWorks adds new instances following an upscaling event but the instances won't start reducing the load until they have been booted and configured. There is no point in raising additional scaling events during that operation, which typically takes several minutes. IgnoreMetricsTime allows you to direct AWS OpsWorks to not raise any scaling events long enough to get the new instances online.

contents.name: _astCpuThreshold
contents.documentation: The CPU utilization threshold, as a percent of the available CPU.

contents.name: _astMemoryThreshold
contents.documentation: The memory utilization threshold, as a percent of the available memory.

contents.name: _astLoadThreshold
contents.documentation: The load threshold. For more information about how load is computed, see Load (computing).

contents.name: _dcName
contents.documentation:
Specifies the operation. You can specify only one command.

For stacks, the following commands are available:

  • execute_recipes: Execute one or more recipes. To specify the recipes, set an Args parameter named recipes to the list of recipes to be executed. For example, to execute phpapp::appsetup, set Args to {"recipes":["phpapp::appsetup"]}.
  • install_dependencies: Install the stack's dependencies.
  • update_custom_cookbooks: Update the stack's custom cookbooks.
  • update_dependencies: Update the stack's dependencies.

For apps, the following commands are available:

  • deploy: Deploy an app. Rails apps have an optional Args parameter named migrate. Set Args to {"migrate":["true"]} to migrate the database. The default setting is {"migrate":["false"]}.
  • rollback Roll the app back to the previous version. When you update an app, AWS OpsWorks stores the previous version, up to a maximum of five versions. You can use this command to roll an app back as many as four versions.
  • start: Start the app's web or application server.
  • stop: Stop the app's web or application server.
  • restart: Restart the app's web or application server.
  • undeploy: Undeploy the app.

contents.name: _dcArgs
contents.documentation:
The arguments of those commands that take arguments. It should be set to a JSON object with the following format:

{"arg_name":["value1", "value2", ...]}

required.name: _dcName
required.documentation:
Specifies the operation. You can specify only one command.

For stacks, the following commands are available:

  • execute_recipes: Execute one or more recipes. To specify the recipes, set an Args parameter named recipes to the list of recipes to be executed. For example, to execute phpapp::appsetup, set Args to {"recipes":["phpapp::appsetup"]}.
  • install_dependencies: Install the stack's dependencies.
  • update_custom_cookbooks: Update the stack's custom cookbooks.
  • update_dependencies: Update the stack's dependencies.

For apps, the following commands are available:

  • deploy: Deploy an app. Rails apps have an optional Args parameter named migrate. Set Args to {"migrate":["true"]} to migrate the database. The default setting is {"migrate":["false"]}.
  • rollback Roll the app back to the previous version. When you update an app, AWS OpsWorks stores the previous version, up to a maximum of five versions. You can use this command to roll an app back as many as four versions.
  • start: Start the app's web or application server.
  • stop: Stop the app's web or application server.
  • restart: Restart the app's web or application server.
  • undeploy: Undeploy the app.

contents.documentation:
The instance's auto scaling type, which has three possible values:

  • AlwaysRunning: A 24/7 instance, which is not affected by auto scaling.
  • TimeBasedAutoScaling: A time-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on a specified schedule.
  • LoadBasedAutoScaling: A load-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on load metrics.

operations.name: AssignVolume
operations.documentation:
Assigns one of the stack's registered Amazon EBS volumes to a specified instance. The volume must first be registered with the stack by calling RegisterVolume. For more information, see Resource Management.

Required Permissions: To use this action, an IAM user must have a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user permissions, see Managing User Permissions.

operations.name: AssociateElasticIp
operations.documentation:
Associates one of the stack's registered Elastic IP addresses with a specified instance. The address must first be registered with the stack by calling RegisterElasticIp. For more information, see Resource Management.

Required Permissions: To use this action, an IAM user must have a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user permissions, see Managing User Permissions.

operations.name: CloneStack
operations.documentation:
Creates a clone of a specified stack. For more information, see Clone a Stack.

Required Permissions: To use this action, an IAM user must have an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user permissions, see Managing User Permissions.

contents.name: _cs1SourceStackId
contents.documentation: The source stack ID.

contents.name: _cs1Name
contents.documentation: The cloned stack name.

contents.name: _cs1Region
contents.documentation: The cloned stack AWS region, such as "us-east-1". For more information about AWS regions, see Regions and Endpoints.

contents.name: _cs1VpcId
contents.documentation:
The ID of the VPC that the cloned stack is to be launched into. It must be in the specified region. All instances will be launched into this VPC, and you cannot change the ID later.

  • If your account supports EC2 Classic, the default value is no VPC.
  • If your account does not support EC2 Classic, the default value is the default VPC for the specified region.

If the VPC ID corresponds to a default VPC and you have specified either the DefaultAvailabilityZone or the DefaultSubnetId parameter only, AWS OpsWorks infers the value of the other parameter. If you specify neither parameter, AWS OpsWorks sets these parameters to the first valid Availability Zone for the specified region and the corresponding default VPC subnet ID, respectively.

If you specify a nondefault VPC ID, note the following:

  • It must belong to a VPC in your account that is in the specified region.
  • You must specify a value for DefaultSubnetId.

For more information on how to use AWS OpsWorks with a VPC, see Running a Stack in a VPC. For more information on default VPC and EC2 Classic, see Supported Platforms.

contents.name: _cs1Attributes
contents.documentation: A list of stack attributes and values as key/value pairs to be added to the cloned stack.

contents.name: _cs1ServiceRoleArn
contents.documentation: The stack AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role, which allows AWS OpsWorks to work with AWS resources on your behalf. You must set this parameter to the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an existing IAM role. If you create a stack by using the AWS OpsWorks console, it creates the role for you. You can obtain an existing stack's IAM ARN programmatically by calling DescribePermissions. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

contents.name: _cs1DefaultInstanceProfileArn
contents.documentation: The ARN of an IAM profile that is the default profile for all of the stack's EC2 instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

contents.name: _cs1DefaultOs
contents.documentation: The cloned stack's default operating system, which must be set to Amazon Linux or Ubuntu 12.04 LTS. The default option is Amazon Linux.

contents.name: _cs1HostnameTheme
contents.documentation:
The stack's host name theme, with spaces are replaced by underscores. The theme is used to generate host names for the stack's instances. By default, HostnameTheme is set to Layer_Dependent, which creates host names by appending integers to the layer's short name. The other themes are:

  • Baked_Goods
  • Clouds
  • European_Cities
  • Fruits
  • Greek_Deities
  • Legendary_Creatures_from_Japan
  • Planets_and_Moons
  • Roman_Deities
  • Scottish_Islands
  • US_Cities
  • Wild_Cats

To obtain a generated host name, call GetHostNameSuggestion, which returns a host name based on the current theme.

contents.name: _cs1DefaultAvailabilityZone
contents.documentation: The cloned stack's default Availability Zone, which must be in the specified region. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints. If you also specify a value for DefaultSubnetId, the subnet must be in the same zone. For more information, see the VpcId parameter description.

contents.name: _cs1DefaultSubnetId
contents.documentation: The stack's default subnet ID. All instances will be launched into this subnet unless you specify otherwise when you create the instance. If you also specify a value for DefaultAvailabilityZone, the subnet must be in the same zone. For information on default values and when this parameter is required, see the VpcId parameter description.

contents.name: _cs1CustomJson
contents.documentation:
A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It is used to override the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values. The string should be in the following format and must escape characters such as '"'.:

"{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"

For more information on custom JSON, see Use Custom JSON to Modify the Stack Configuration JSON

contents.name: _cs1ConfigurationManager
contents.documentation: The configuration manager. When you clone a stack we recommend that you use the configuration manager to specify the Chef version, 0.9, 11.4, or 11.10. The default value is currently 11.4.

contents.name: _cs1ChefConfiguration
contents.documentation: A ChefConfiguration object that specifies whether to enable Berkshelf and the Berkshelf version on Chef 11.10 stacks. For more information, see Create a New Stack.

contents.name: _cs1UseCustomCookbooks
contents.documentation: Whether to use custom cookbooks.

contents.name: _cs1UseOpsworksSecurityGroups
contents.documentation:
Whether to associate the AWS OpsWorks built-in security groups with the stack's layers.

AWS OpsWorks provides a standard set of built-in security groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by default. With UseOpsworksSecurityGroups you can instead provide your own custom security groups. UseOpsworksSecurityGroups has the following settings:

  • True - AWS OpsWorks automatically associates the appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting). You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you create it but you cannot delete the built-in security group.
  • False - AWS OpsWorks does not associate built-in security groups with layers. You must create appropriate EC2 security groups and associate a security group with each layer that you create. However, you can still manually associate a built-in security group with a layer on creation; custom security groups are required only for those layers that need custom settings.

For more information, see Create a New Stack.

contents.name: _cs1DefaultSshKeyName
contents.documentation: A default SSH key for the stack instances. You can override this value when you create or update an instance.

contents.name: _cs1ClonePermissions
contents.documentation: Whether to clone the source stack's permissions.

contents.name: _cs1CloneAppIds
contents.documentation: A list of source stack app IDs to be included in the cloned stack.

contents.name: _cs1DefaultRootDeviceType
contents.documentation: The default root device type. This value is used by default for all instances in the cloned stack, but you can override it when you create an instance. For more information, see Storage for the Root Device.

required.name: _cs1ServiceRoleArn
required.documentation: The stack AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role, which allows AWS OpsWorks to work with AWS resources on your behalf. You must set this parameter to the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an existing IAM role. If you create a stack by using the AWS OpsWorks console, it creates the role for you. You can obtain an existing stack's IAM ARN programmatically by calling DescribePermissions. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

optional.name: _cs1Name
optional.documentation: The cloned stack name.

optional.name: _cs1Region
optional.documentation: The cloned stack AWS region, such as "us-east-1". For more information about AWS regions, see Regions and Endpoints.

optional.name: _cs1VpcId
optional.documentation:
The ID of the VPC that the cloned stack is to be launched into. It must be in the specified region. All instances will be launched into this VPC, and you cannot change the ID later.

  • If your account supports EC2 Classic, the default value is no VPC.
  • If your account does not support EC2 Classic, the default value is the default VPC for the specified region.

If the VPC ID corresponds to a default VPC and you have specified either the DefaultAvailabilityZone or the DefaultSubnetId parameter only, AWS OpsWorks infers the value of the other parameter. If you specify neither parameter, AWS OpsWorks sets these parameters to the first valid Availability Zone for the specified region and the corresponding default VPC subnet ID, respectively.

If you specify a nondefault VPC ID, note the following:

  • It must belong to a VPC in your account that is in the specified region.
  • You must specify a value for DefaultSubnetId.

For more information on how to use AWS OpsWorks with a VPC, see Running a Stack in a VPC. For more information on default VPC and EC2 Classic, see Supported Platforms.

optional.name: _cs1Attributes
optional.documentation: A list of stack attributes and values as key/value pairs to be added to the cloned stack.

optional.name: _cs1DefaultInstanceProfileArn
optional.documentation: The ARN of an IAM profile that is the default profile for all of the stack's EC2 instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

optional.name: _cs1DefaultOs
optional.documentation: The cloned stack's default operating system, which must be set to Amazon Linux or Ubuntu 12.04 LTS. The default option is Amazon Linux.

optional.name: _cs1HostnameTheme
optional.documentation:
The stack's host name theme, with spaces are replaced by underscores. The theme is used to generate host names for the stack's instances. By default, HostnameTheme is set to Layer_Dependent, which creates host names by appending integers to the layer's short name. The other themes are:

  • Baked_Goods
  • Clouds
  • European_Cities
  • Fruits
  • Greek_Deities
  • Legendary_Creatures_from_Japan
  • Planets_and_Moons
  • Roman_Deities
  • Scottish_Islands
  • US_Cities
  • Wild_Cats

To obtain a generated host name, call GetHostNameSuggestion, which returns a host name based on the current theme.

optional.name: _cs1DefaultSubnetId
optional.documentation: The stack's default subnet ID. All instances will be launched into this subnet unless you specify otherwise when you create the instance. If you also specify a value for DefaultAvailabilityZone, the subnet must be in the same zone. For information on default values and when this parameter is required, see the VpcId parameter description.

optional.name: _cs1UseOpsworksSecurityGroups

AWS OpsWorks provides a standard set of built-in security groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by default. With UseOpsworksSecurityGroups you can instead provide your own custom security groups. UseOpsworksSecurityGroups has the following settings:

  • True - AWS OpsWorks automatically associates the appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting). You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you create it but you cannot delete the built-in security group.
  • False - AWS OpsWorks does not associate built-in security groups with layers. You must create appropriate EC2 security groups and associate a security group with each layer that you create. However, you can still manually associate a built-in security group with a layer on creation; custom security groups are required only for those layers that need custom settings.

For more information, see Create a New Stack.

operations.name: CreateApp
operations.documentation:
Creates an app for a specified stack. For more information, see Creating Apps.

Required Permissions: To use this action, an IAM user must have a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user permissions, see Managing User Permissions.

contents.name: _caDataSources

contents.name: _caType
contents.documentation: The app type. Each supported type is associated with a particular layer. For example, PHP applications are associated with a PHP layer. AWS OpsWorks deploys an application to those instances that are members of the corresponding layer.

contents.name: _caAppSource
contents.documentation: A Source object that specifies the app repository.

contents.name: _caDomains
contents.documentation: The app virtual host settings, with multiple domains separated by commas. For example: 'www.example.com, example.com'

contents.name: _caEnableSsl

operations.name: CreateDeployment
operations.documentation:
Deploys a stack or app.

  • App deployment generates a deploy event, which runs the associated recipes and passes them a JSON stack configuration object that includes information about the app.
  • Stack deployment runs the deploy recipes but does not raise an event.

For more information, see Deploying Apps and Run Stack Commands.

Required Permissions: To use this action, an IAM user must have a Deploy or Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user permissions, see Managing User Permissions.

contents.documentation: The stack ID.

contents.name: _cdAppId

contents.name: _cdInstanceIds
contents.documentation: The instance IDs for the deployment targets.

contents.documentation: A DeploymentCommand object that specifies the deployment command and any associated arguments.

For more information on custom JSON, see Use Custom JSON to Modify the Stack Configuration JSON.

operations.name: CreateInstance
operations.documentation:
Creates an instance in a specified stack. For more information, see Adding an Instance to a Layer.

Required Permissions: To use this action, an IAM user must have a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user permissions, see Managing User Permissions.

contents.name: _ciStackId
contents.documentation: The stack ID.

contents.name: _ciLayerIds
contents.documentation: An array that contains the instance layer IDs.

contents.name: _ciInstanceType
contents.documentation: The instance type. AWS OpsWorks supports all instance types except Cluster Compute, Cluster GPU, and High Memory Cluster. For more information, see Instance Families and Types. The parameter values that you use to specify the various types are in the API Name column of the Available Instance Types table.

contents.name: _ciAutoScalingType
contents.documentation:
The instance auto scaling type, which has three possible values:

  • AlwaysRunning: A 24/7 instance, which is not affected by auto scaling.
  • TimeBasedAutoScaling: A time-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on a specified schedule. To specify the schedule, call SetTimeBasedAutoScaling.
  • LoadBasedAutoScaling: A load-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on load metrics. To use load-based auto scaling, you must enable it for the instance layer and configure the thresholds by calling SetLoadBasedAutoScaling.

contents.name: _ciHostname
contents.documentation: The instance host name.

contents.name: _ciOs
contents.documentation:
The instance operating system, which must be set to one of the following.

  • Standard operating systems: Amazon Linux or Ubuntu 12.04 LTS
  • Custom AMIs: Custom

The default option is Amazon Linux. If you set this parameter to Custom, you must use the CreateInstance action's AmiId parameter to specify the custom AMI that you want to use. For more information on the standard operating systems, see Operating SystemsFor more information on how to use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see Using Custom AMIs.

contents.name: _ciAmiId
contents.documentation: A custom AMI ID to be used to create the instance. The AMI should be based on one of the standard AWS OpsWorks APIs: Amazon Linux or Ubuntu 12.04 LTS. For more information, see Instances

contents.name: _ciSshKeyName
contents.documentation: The instance SSH key name.

contents.name: _ciAvailabilityZone
contents.documentation: The instance Availability Zone. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints.

contents.name: _ciVirtualizationType
contents.documentation: The instance's virtualization type, paravirtual or hvm.

contents.name: _ciSubnetId
contents.documentation: The ID of the instance's subnet. If the stack is running in a VPC, you can use this parameter to override the stack's default subnet ID value and direct AWS OpsWorks to launch the instance in a different subnet.

contents.name: _ciArchitecture
contents.documentation: The instance architecture. The default option is x86_64. Instance types do not necessarily support both architectures. For a list of the architectures that are supported by the different instance types, see Instance Families and Types.

contents.name: _ciRootDeviceType
contents.documentation: The instance root device type. For more information, see Storage for the Root Device.

contents.name: _ciInstallUpdatesOnBoot
contents.documentation: Whether to install operating system and package updates when the instance boots. The default value is true. To control when updates are installed, set this value to false. You must then update your instances manually by using CreateDeployment to run the update_dependencies stack command or manually running yum (Amazon Linux) or apt-get (Ubuntu) on the instances.

contents.name: _ciEbsOptimized
contents.documentation: Whether to create an Amazon EBS-optimized instance.

fields.documentation: The instance architecture. The default option is x86_64. Instance types do not necessarily support both architectures. For a list of the architectures that are supported by the different instance types, see Instance Families and Types.

fields.name: _ciAutoScalingType
fields.documentation:
The instance auto scaling type, which has three possible values:

  • AlwaysRunning: A 24/7 instance, which is not affected by auto scaling.
  • TimeBasedAutoScaling: A time-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on a specified schedule. To specify the schedule, call SetTimeBasedAutoScaling.
  • LoadBasedAutoScaling: A load-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on load metrics. To use load-based auto scaling, you must enable it for the instance layer and configure the thresholds by calling SetLoadBasedAutoScaling.

fields.name: _ciAvailabilityZone
fields.documentation: The instance Availability Zone. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints.

fields.name: _ciEbsOptimized
fields.documentation: Whether to create an Amazon EBS-optimized instance.

fields.name: _ciHostname
fields.documentation: The instance host name.

fields.name: _ciInstallUpdatesOnBoot
fields.documentation: Whether to install operating system and package updates when the instance boots. The default value is true. To control when updates are installed, set this value to false. You must then update your instances manually by using CreateDeployment to run the update_dependencies stack command or manually running yum (Amazon Linux) or apt-get (Ubuntu) on the instances.

fields.name: _ciInstanceType
fields.documentation: The instance type. AWS OpsWorks supports all instance types except Cluster Compute, Cluster GPU, and High Memory Cluster. For more information, see Instance Families and Types. The parameter values that you use to specify the various types are in the API Name column of the Available Instance Types table.

fields.name: _ciLayerIds
fields.documentation: An array that contains the instance layer IDs.

fields.name: _ciOs
fields.documentation:
The instance operating system, which must be set to one of the following.

  • Standard operating systems: Amazon Linux or Ubuntu 12.04 LTS
  • Custom AMIs: Custom

The default option is Amazon Linux. If you set this parameter to Custom, you must use the CreateInstance action's AmiId parameter to specify the custom AMI that you want to use. For more information on the standard operating systems, see Operating SystemsFor more information on how to use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see Using Custom AMIs.

fields.name: _ciRootDeviceType
fields.documentation: The instance root device type. For more information, see Storage for the Root Device.

fields.name: _ciSshKeyName
fields.documentation: The instance SSH key name.

fields.name: _ciStackId
fields.documentation: The stack ID.

fields.name: _ciSubnetId
fields.documentation: The ID of the instance's subnet. If the stack is running in a VPC, you can use this parameter to override the stack's default subnet ID value and direct AWS OpsWorks to launch the instance in a different subnet.

fields.name: _ciVirtualizationType
fields.documentation: The instance's virtualization type, paravirtual or hvm.

operations.name: CreateLayer
operations.documentation:
Creates a layer. For more information, see How to Create a Layer.

Required Permissions: To use this action, an IAM user must have a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user permissions, see Managing User Permissions.

contents.name: _clStackId
contents.documentation: The layer stack ID.

contents.name: _clType
contents.documentation:
The layer type. A stack cannot have more than one built-in layer of the same type. It can have any number of custom layers. This parameter must be set to one of the following:

  • custom: A custom layer
  • db-master: A MySQL layer
  • java-app: A Java App Server layer
  • rails-app: A Rails App Server layer
  • lb: An HAProxy layer
  • memcached: A Memcached layer
  • monitoring-master: A Ganglia layer
  • nodejs-app: A Node.js App Server layer
  • php-app: A PHP App Server layer
  • web: A Static Web Server layer

contents.name: _clName
contents.documentation: The layer name, which is used by the console.

contents.name: _clShortname
contents.documentation: The layer short name, which is used internally by AWS OpsWorks and by Chef recipes. The short name is also used as the name for the directory where your app files are installed. It can have a maximum of 200 characters, which are limited to the alphanumeric characters, '-', '_', and '.'.

contents.name: _clAttributes
contents.documentation: One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack attributes.

contents.name: _clCustomInstanceProfileArn
contents.documentation: The ARN of an IAM profile that to be used for the layer's EC2 instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

contents.name: _clCustomSecurityGroupIds
contents.documentation: An array containing the layer custom security group IDs.

contents.name: _clPackages
contents.documentation: An array of Package objects that describe the layer packages.

contents.name: _clVolumeConfigurations
contents.documentation: A VolumeConfigurations object that describes the layer's Amazon EBS volumes.

contents.name: _clEnableAutoHealing
contents.documentation: Whether to disable auto healing for the layer.

contents.name: _clAutoAssignElasticIps
contents.documentation: Whether to automatically assign an Elastic IP address to the layer's instances. For more information, see How to Edit a Layer.

contents.name: _clAutoAssignPublicIps
contents.documentation: For stacks that are running in a VPC, whether to automatically assign a public IP address to the layer's instances. For more information, see How to Edit a Layer.

contents.name: _clCustomRecipes
contents.documentation: A LayerCustomRecipes object that specifies the layer custom recipes.

contents.name: _clInstallUpdatesOnBoot
contents.documentation: Whether to install operating system and package updates when the instance boots. The default value is true. To control when updates are installed, set this value to false. You must then update your instances manually by using CreateDeployment to run the update_dependencies stack command or manually running yum (Amazon Linux) or apt-get (Ubuntu) on the instances.

contents.name: _clUseEbsOptimizedInstances
contents.documentation: Whether to use Amazon EBS-optimized instances.

field.name: _csr1StackId

contents.documentation: The stack ID, which is an opaque string that you use to identify the stack when performing actions such as DescribeStacks.

operations.name: CreateStack
operations.documentation:
Creates a new stack. For more information, see Create a New Stack.

Required Permissions: To use this action, an IAM user must have an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user permissions, see Managing User Permissions.

contents.name: _csName
contents.documentation: The stack name.

contents.name: _csRegion
contents.documentation: The stack AWS region, such as "us-east-1". For more information about Amazon regions, see Regions and Endpoints.

contents.name: _csVpcId
contents.documentation:
The ID of the VPC that the stack is to be launched into. It must be in the specified region. All instances will be launched into this VPC, and you cannot change the ID later.

  • If your account supports EC2 Classic, the default value is no VPC.
  • If your account does not support EC2 Classic, the default value is the default VPC for the specified region.

If the VPC ID corresponds to a default VPC and you have specified either the DefaultAvailabilityZone or the DefaultSubnetId parameter only, AWS OpsWorks infers the value of the other parameter. If you specify neither parameter, AWS OpsWorks sets these parameters to the first valid Availability Zone for the specified region and the corresponding default VPC subnet ID, respectively.

If you specify a nondefault VPC ID, note the following:

  • It must belong to a VPC in your account that is in the specified region.
  • You must specify a value for DefaultSubnetId.

For more information on how to use AWS OpsWorks with a VPC, see Running a Stack in a VPC. For more information on default VPC and EC2 Classic, see Supported Platforms.

contents.name: _csAttributes
contents.documentation: One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack attributes.

contents.name: _csServiceRoleArn
contents.documentation: The stack AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role, which allows AWS OpsWorks to work with AWS resources on your behalf. You must set this parameter to the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an existing IAM role. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

contents.name: _csDefaultInstanceProfileArn
contents.documentation: The ARN of an IAM profile that is the default profile for all of the stack's EC2 instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

contents.name: _csDefaultOs
contents.documentation: The stack's default operating system, which must be set to Amazon Linux or Ubuntu 12.04 LTS. The default option is Amazon Linux.

contents.name: _csHostnameTheme
contents.documentation:
The stack's host name theme, with spaces are replaced by underscores. The theme is used to generate host names for the stack's instances. By default, HostnameTheme is set to Layer_Dependent, which creates host names by appending integers to the layer's short name. The other themes are:

  • Baked_Goods
  • Clouds
  • European_Cities
  • Fruits
  • Greek_Deities
  • Legendary_Creatures_from_Japan
  • Planets_and_Moons
  • Roman_Deities
  • Scottish_Islands
  • US_Cities
  • Wild_Cats

To obtain a generated host name, call GetHostNameSuggestion, which returns a host name based on the current theme.

contents.name: _csDefaultAvailabilityZone
contents.documentation: The stack's default Availability Zone, which must be in the specified region. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints. If you also specify a value for DefaultSubnetId, the subnet must be in the same zone. For more information, see the VpcId parameter description.

contents.name: _csDefaultSubnetId
contents.documentation: The stack's default subnet ID. All instances will be launched into this subnet unless you specify otherwise when you create the instance. If you also specify a value for DefaultAvailabilityZone, the subnet must be in that zone. For information on default values and when this parameter is required, see the VpcId parameter description.

contents.name: _csCustomJson
contents.documentation:
A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It is used to override the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values. The string should be in the following format and must escape characters such as '"'.:

"{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"

For more information on custom JSON, see Use Custom JSON to Modify the Stack Configuration JSON.

contents.name: _csConfigurationManager
contents.documentation: The configuration manager. When you clone a stack we recommend that you use the configuration manager to specify the Chef version, 0.9, 11.4, or 11.10. The default value is currently 11.4.

contents.name: _csChefConfiguration
contents.documentation: A ChefConfiguration object that specifies whether to enable Berkshelf and the Berkshelf version on Chef 11.10 stacks. For more information, see Create a New Stack.

contents.name: _csUseCustomCookbooks
contents.documentation: Whether the stack uses custom cookbooks.

contents.name: _csUseOpsworksSecurityGroups
contents.documentation:
Whether to associate the AWS OpsWorks built-in security groups with the stack's layers.

AWS OpsWorks provides a standard set of built-in security groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by default. With UseOpsworksSecurityGroups you can instead provide your own custom security groups. UseOpsworksSecurityGroups has the following settings:

  • True - AWS OpsWorks automatically associates the appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting). You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you create it but you cannot delete the built-in security group.
  • False - AWS OpsWorks does not associate built-in security groups with layers. You must create appropriate EC2 security groups and associate a security group with each layer that you create. However, you can still manually associate a built-in security group with a layer on creation; custom security groups are required only for those layers that need custom settings.

For more information, see Create a New Stack.

contents.name: _csDefaultSshKeyName
contents.documentation: A default SSH key for the stack instances. You can override this value when you create or update an instance.

contents.name: _csDefaultRootDeviceType
contents.documentation: The default root device type. This value is used by default for all instances in the stack, but you can override it when you create an instance. The default option is instance-store. For more information, see Storage for the Root Device.

If the VPC ID corresponds to a default VPC and you have specified either the DefaultAvailabilityZone or the DefaultSubnetId parameter only, AWS OpsWorks infers the value of the other parameter. If you specify neither parameter, AWS OpsWorks sets these parameters to the first valid Availability Zone for the specified region and the corresponding default VPC subnet ID, respectively.

If you specify a nondefault VPC ID, note the following:

  • It must belong to a VPC in your account that is in the specified region.
  • You must specify a value for DefaultSubnetId.

For more information on how to use AWS OpsWorks with a VPC, see Running a Stack in a VPC. For more information on default VPC and EC2 Classic, see Supported Platforms.

operations.name: UpdateInstance
operations.documentation:
Updates a specified instance.

Required Permissions: To use this action, an IAM user must have a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user permissions, see Managing User Permissions.

contents.name: _uiInstanceId
contents.documentation: The instance ID.

contents.name: _uiLayerIds
contents.documentation: The instance's layer IDs.

contents.name: _uiInstanceType
contents.documentation: The instance type. AWS OpsWorks supports all instance types except Cluster Compute, Cluster GPU, and High Memory Cluster. For more information, see Instance Families and Types. The parameter values that you use to specify the various types are in the API Name column of the Available Instance Types table.

contents.name: _uiAutoScalingType
contents.documentation:
The instance's auto scaling type, which has three possible values:

  • AlwaysRunning: A 24/7 instance, which is not affected by auto scaling.
  • TimeBasedAutoScaling: A time-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on a specified schedule.
  • LoadBasedAutoScaling: A load-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on load metrics.

contents.name: _uiHostname
contents.documentation: The instance host name.

contents.name: _uiOs
contents.documentation:
The instance operating system, which must be set to one of the following.

  • Standard operating systems: Amazon Linux or Ubuntu 12.04 LTS
  • Custom AMIs: Custom

The default option is Amazon Linux. If you set this parameter to Custom, you must use the CreateInstance action's AmiId parameter to specify the custom AMI that you want to use. For more information on the standard operating systems, see Operating SystemsFor more information on how to use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see Using Custom AMIs.

contents.name: _uiAmiId
contents.documentation: A custom AMI ID to be used to create the instance. The AMI should be based on one of the standard AWS OpsWorks APIs: Amazon Linux or Ubuntu 12.04 LTS. For more information, see Instances

contents.name: _uiSshKeyName
contents.documentation: The instance SSH key name.

contents.name: _uiArchitecture
contents.documentation: The instance architecture. Instance types do not necessarily support both architectures. For a list of the architectures that are supported by the different instance types, see Instance Families and Types.

contents.name: _uiInstallUpdatesOnBoot
contents.documentation: Whether to install operating system and package updates when the instance boots. The default value is true. To control when updates are installed, set this value to false. You must then update your instances manually by using CreateDeployment to run the update_dependencies stack command or manually running yum (Amazon Linux) or apt-get (Ubuntu) on the instances.

contents.name: _uiEbsOptimized
contents.documentation: Whether this is an Amazon EBS-optimized instance.

optional.name: _uiLayerIds
optional.documentation: The instance's layer IDs.

optional.name: _uiInstanceType
optional.documentation: The instance type. AWS OpsWorks supports all instance types except Cluster Compute, Cluster GPU, and High Memory Cluster. optional.documentation: Whether this is an Amazon EBS-optimized instance.

fields.name: _uiAmiId
fields.documentation: A custom AMI ID to be used to create the instance. The AMI should be based on one of the standard AWS OpsWorks APIs: Amazon Linux or Ubuntu 12.04 LTS. For more information, see Instances

fields.name: _uiArchitecture
fields.documentation: The instance architecture. Instance types do not necessarily support both architectures. For a list of the architectures that are supported by the different instance types, see Instance Families and Types.

fields.name: _uiAutoScalingType
fields.documentation:
The instance's auto scaling type, which has three possible values:

  • AlwaysRunning: A 24/7 instance, which is not affected by auto scaling.
  • TimeBasedAutoScaling: A time-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on a specified schedule.
  • LoadBasedAutoScaling: A load-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on load metrics.

fields.name: _uiEbsOptimized
fields.documentation: Whether this is an Amazon EBS-optimized instance.

fields.name: _uiHostname
fields.documentation: The instance host name.

fields.name: _uiInstallUpdatesOnBoot
fields.documentation: Whether to install operating system and package updates when the instance boots. The default value is true. To control when updates are installed, set this value to false. You must then update your instances manually by using CreateDeployment to run the update_dependencies stack command or manually running yum (Amazon Linux) or apt-get (Ubuntu) on the instances.

fields.name: _uiInstanceId
fields.documentation: The instance ID.

fields.name: _uiInstanceType
fields.documentation: The instance type. AWS OpsWorks supports all instance types except Cluster Compute, Cluster GPU, and High Memory Cluster. For more information, see Instance Families and Types. The parameter values that you use to specify the various types are in the API Name column of the Available Instance Types table.

fields.name: _uiLayerIds
fields.documentation: The instance's layer IDs.

fields.name: _uiOs
fields.documentation:
The instance operating system, which must be set to one of the following.

  • Standard operating systems: Amazon Linux or Ubuntu 12.04 LTS
  • Custom AMIs: Custom

The default option is Amazon Linux. If you set this parameter to Custom, you must use the CreateInstance action's AmiId parameter to specify the custom AMI that you want to use. For more information on the standard operating systems, see Operating SystemsFor more information on how to use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see Using Custom AMIs.

fields.name: _uiSshKeyName
fields.documentation: The instance SSH key name.

operations.name: UpdateLayer

Required Permissions: To use this action, an IAM user must have a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user permissions, see Managing User Permissions.

contents.name: _ulName
contents.documentation: The layer name, which is used by the console.

contents.name: _ulShortname
contents.documentation: The layer short name, which is used internally by AWS OpsWorksand by Chef. The short name is also used as the name for the directory where your app files are installed. It can have a maximum of 200 characters and must be in the following format: /\A[a-z0-9\-\_\.]+\Z/.

contents.name: _ulAttributes
contents.documentation: One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack attributes.

contents.name: _ulCustomInstanceProfileArn

contents.name: _ulCustomSecurityGroupIds

contents.name: _ulPackages

contents.name: _ulVolumeConfigurations

contents.name: _ulEnableAutoHealing
contents.documentation: Whether to disable auto healing for the layer.

contents.name: _ulAutoAssignElasticIps

contents.name: _ulAutoAssignPublicIps

contents.name: _ulCustomRecipes

operations.name: UpdateStack
operations.documentation:
Updates a specified stack.

Required Permissions: To use this action, an IAM user must have a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user permissions, see Managing User Permissions.

contents.name: _usStackId
contents.documentation: The stack ID.

contents.name: _usName
contents.documentation: The stack's new name.

contents.name: _usAttributes
contents.documentation: One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack attributes.

contents.name: _usServiceRoleArn
contents.documentation: The stack AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role, which allows AWS OpsWorks to work with AWS resources on your behalf. You must set this parameter to the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an existing IAM role. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

contents.name: _usDefaultInstanceProfileArn
contents.documentation: The ARN of an IAM profile that is the default profile for all of the stack's EC2 instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

contents.name: _usDefaultOs
contents.documentation: The stack's default operating system, which must be set to Amazon Linux or Ubuntu 12.04 LTS. The default option is Amazon Linux.

contents.name: _usHostnameTheme
contents.documentation:
The stack's new host name theme, with spaces are replaced by underscores. The theme is used to generate host names for the stack's instances. By default, HostnameTheme is set to Layer_Dependent, which creates host names by appending integers to the layer's short name. The other themes are:

  • Baked_Goods
  • Clouds
  • European_Cities
  • Fruits
  • Greek_Deities
  • Legendary_Creatures_from_Japan
  • Planets_and_Moons
  • Roman_Deities
  • Scottish_Islands
  • US_Cities
  • Wild_Cats

To obtain a generated host name, call GetHostNameSuggestion, which returns a host name based on the current theme.

contents.name: _usDefaultAvailabilityZone
contents.documentation: The stack's default Availability Zone, which must be in the specified region. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints. If you also specify a value for DefaultSubnetId, the subnet must be in the same zone. For more information, see CreateStack.

contents.name: _usDefaultSubnetId
contents.documentation: The stack's default subnet ID. All instances will be launched into this subnet unless you specify otherwise when you create the instance. If you also specify a value for DefaultAvailabilityZone, the subnet must be in that zone. For more information, see CreateStack.

contents.name: _usCustomJson
contents.documentation:
A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It is used to override the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values. The string should be in the following format and must escape characters such as '"'.:

"{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"

For more information on custom JSON, see Use Custom JSON to Modify the Stack Configuration JSON.

contents.name: _usConfigurationManager
contents.documentation: The configuration manager. When you clone a stack we recommend that you use the configuration manager to specify the Chef version, 0.9, 11.4, or 11.10. The default value is currently 11.4.

contents.name: _usChefConfiguration
contents.documentation: A ChefConfiguration object that specifies whether to enable Berkshelf and the Berkshelf version on Chef 11.10 stacks. For more information, see Create a New Stack.

contents.name: _usUseCustomCookbooks
contents.documentation: Whether the stack uses custom cookbooks.

contents.name: _usDefaultSshKeyName
contents.documentation: A default SSH key for the stack instances. You can override this value when you create or update an instance.

contents.name: _usDefaultRootDeviceType
contents.documentation: The default root device type. This value is used by default for all instances in the stack, but you can override it when you create an instance. For more information, see Storage for the Root Device.

contents.name: _usUseOpsworksSecurityGroups
contents.documentation:
Whether to associate the AWS OpsWorks built-in security groups with the stack's layers.

AWS OpsWorks provides a standard set of built-in security groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by default. UseOpsworksSecurityGroups allows you to instead provide your own custom security groups. UseOpsworksSecurityGroups has the following settings:

  • True - AWS OpsWorks automatically associates the appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting). You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you create it but you cannot delete the built-in security group.
  • False - AWS OpsWorks does not associate built-in security groups with layers. You must create appropriate EC2 security groups and associate a security group with each layer that you create. However, you can still manually associate a built-in security group with a layer on creation; custom security groups are required only for those layers that need custom settings.

For more information, see Create a New Stack.

To obtain a generated host name, call GetHostNameSuggestion, which returns a host name based on the current theme.

operations.name: UpdateUserProfile
operations.documentation:
Updates a specified user profile.

Required Permissions: To use this action, an IAM user must have an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user permissions, see Managing User Permissions.

contents.name: _uupIamUserArn
contents.documentation: The user IAM ARN.

contents.name: _uupSshUsername
contents.documentation: The user's SSH user name. The allowable characters are [a-z], [A-Z], [0-9], '-', and '_'. If the specified name includes other punctuation marks, AWS OpsWorks removes them. For example, my.name will be changed to myname. If you do not specify an SSH user name, AWS OpsWorks generates one from the IAM user name.

contents.name: _uupSshPublicKey
contents.documentation: The user's new SSH public key.

contents.name: _uupAllowSelfManagement
contents.documentation: Whether users can specify their own SSH public key through the My Settings page. For more information, see Managing User Permissions.

optional.documentation: The user's SSH user name. The allowable characters are [a-z], [A-Z], [0-9], '-', and '_'. If the specified name includes other punctuation marks, AWS OpsWorks removes them. For example, my.name will be changed to myname. If you do not specify an SSH user name, AWS OpsWorks generates one from the IAM user name.
